title: Electricity Cost Calculator

seo.title: Electricity Cost Calculator | Estimate Appliance Energy Bills
seo.description: Calculate the daily, monthly, and annual electricity cost of any appliance. Enter wattage, daily usage hours, and your electricity rate (cost per kWh) to estimate your energy consumption and bills.

inputs.label: Appliance Power
inputs.description: The power consumption of the appliance in watts.

inputs.label: Hours Used Per Day
inputs.description: The average number of hours the appliance is used per day.

inputs.label: Electricity Rate
inputs.description: Your electricity cost per kilowatt-hour (kWh). Check your electricity bill.

formula: let kwh_per_day = (appliance_power_watts / 1000) * hours_per_day; let daily_cost = kwh_per_day * electricity_rate_kwh; let monthly_cost = daily_cost * 30.44; let annual_cost = daily_cost * 365.25; return { daily_kwh, daily_cost, monthly_cost, annual_cost };

outputs.label: Daily kWh
outputs.description: Kilowatt-hours consumed by the appliance per day.

outputs.label: Daily Cost
outputs.description: Estimated cost to run the appliance per day.

outputs.label: Monthly Cost
outputs.description: Estimated cost to run the appliance per month (average 30.44 days).

outputs.label: Annual Cost
outputs.description: Estimated cost to run the appliance per year (average 365.25 days).

faq.question: How is electricity cost calculated?
faq.answer: The electricity cost is calculated by multiplying the appliance's power consumption (in kilowatts) by the hours it's used, and then by your electricity rate per kilowatt-hour (kWh). The formula is: (Watts / 1000) * Hours Used * Cost per kWh.

faq.question: Where can I find my electricity rate (cost per kWh)?
faq.answer: Your electricity rate per kWh is typically listed on your monthly electricity bill. It may vary based on your plan, time of use, and location.

faq.question: What is kWh?
faq.answer: kWh stands for kilowatt-hour, which is a unit of energy equal to 1,000 watt-hours. It represents the energy consumed by a 1,000-watt appliance running for one hour. Electricity companies bill you based on your kWh consumption.
